title: Severe Hyperacusis and Tinnitus
chief_complaint: The sounds in the waiting room were incredibly bothersome. Eating sounds cause my tinnitus to become unbearable, and I can't sleep through the night.

problem_summary.onset: Sound intolerance began approximately 1 year ago; tinnitus began abruptly 2 months ago.
problem_summary.course: Worsened substantially with the onset of tinnitus; symptoms exacerbated during quarantine.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Anxiety, sleep disturbance, significant weight loss (inability to chew/swallow due to noise), reactive tinnitus.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Catastrophic (10/10) effect on life. Patient removes sound sources from home, wears ear protection in quiet, and fears loud sounds (phonophobia).
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking relief from sound intolerance and tinnitus.

history.prior_management: Referred to speech and hearing clinic.
history.patient_goals: Patient did not understand hyperacusis diagnosis at this time.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Normal hearing sensitivity from 250-6000 Hz in the left ear and 250-4000 Hz in the right ear. Mild-to-moderate high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss at 8000 Hz bilaterally.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Excellent word recognition ability bilaterally at conversational levels.

history.present_illness: Patient waited in restroom to avoid waiting room noise. Flinched at door opening, otoscope placement, and normal speaking volumes.
history.otologic_history: Otoscopy unremarkable. Immittance deferred due to severe sound intolerance.
history.noise_exposure_history: Describes 'loud' as a car passing by.
history.medical_psych_history: Symptoms consistent with anxiety disorder (DSM-5 criteria).
history.prior_management: Used phone app sound generator but found it ineffective. Wears ear protection in quiet.
history.patient_goals: Reduce sound intolerance and tinnitus disturbance.

tests.name: Self-report scales
tests.key_findings: Scores indicate catastrophic handicap and a very big problem.

tests.name: Ultra-high-frequency audiometry
tests.key_findings: Moderate-to-severe loss from 9,000 to 14,000 Hz. No responses above 14,000 Hz.

tests.name: Loudness Discomfort Levels (LDL)
tests.key_findings: Significantly reduced sound tolerance bilaterally. Tolerance for tones was worse than for speech.

tests.name: Tinnitus Evaluation
tests.key_findings: Pitch/loudness match and minimum masking completed. Residual inhibition testing stopped early due to discomfort.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal hearing sensitivity through 4000-6000 Hz, dropping to a mild-to-moderate loss at 8000 Hz and moderate-to-severe ultra-high-frequency loss. The primary audiological finding is severe hyperacusis with collapsed Loudness Discomfort Levels (20-30 dB HL for tones), accompanied by catastrophic tinnitus distress (THI 84).
counseling_points: Hyperacusis is not a hearing loss, but a sensitivity where the brain's 'volume control' is turned up too high.
Over-protection of ears (wearing plugs in quiet) can actually make the sensitivity worse over time.
We need to gradually reintroduce sound to the auditory system (desensitization) rather than avoiding it.
Reactive tinnitus (spikes in ringing after noise) is common with this condition and usually settles back down.
notes_for_actor: You are extremely jumpy and anxious. Flinch visibly at small sounds like a pen clicking, a door closing, or the doctor speaking at a normal volume.
You are terrified of eating because the chewing noise spikes your tinnitus.
You have lost weight because you are afraid to chew.
You are wearing earplugs or muffs when you enter, or you are covering your ears.
